stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the western-themed level, 'Grand Sand Badland.' The main tasks included implementing swinging saloon doors, coding a feature for a bartender's hat to grow, fixing a duel minigame, and creating a new system to pitch individual sound effects. The stream featured significant debugging, community interaction, and iteration on 3D models and textures.

development_findings.summary: The project's primary performance issue is that it is bottlenecked by the N64's Reality Signal Processor (RSP), a significant technical constraint.
The team is relying on a contributor named Sauren, who is working on a new version of F3DEX (FBDX3), to hopefully alleviate the RSP bottleneck.
The Western level is facing memory constraints, which prevents the addition of new character models and limits design possibilities like a new minigame.
Kaze spent a significant amount of time debugging the physics for swinging saloon doors, with the issue ultimately being a simple logic error in the code.
development_findings.quote: It was all because I used fucking face angle instead of angle to Mario.

development_findings.summary: While implementing a new audio feature, Kaze refactored the code to ensure that the ability to pitch sounds would have no performance cost unless it was actively being used, reflecting a core optimization principle.
development_findings.quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost. If you're not using that part of codes.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a system to detect emulator savestate usage by checking for a mismatch between the game's memory and the EEPROM data, triggering an in-game event.
The design of an easter egg where a bartender's hat grows was tied to the total number of stars collected in the level for clarity, rather than specific story-related missions.
Kaze contrasts his project's philosophy of creating a 'new experience' with other hacks that he feels focus more on level design using vanilla Mario 64 mechanics.
development_findings.quote: Brody's necks are very much just like here's a level go play in it. It's not like here's a new experience go experience it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes in taking all criticism seriously and reviewing it objectively, even if he ultimately decides to ignore it.
context_findings.quote: Leaving a comment, critiquing whatever I made is always good... Always look at criticism very objectively. And unemotionally.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong opinion against self-inserting characters into games, viewing it as 'cringe'.
context_findings.quote: I don't put myself in my games. I think self-inserts is a little cringe.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy favors creating features to solve existing design problems rather than inventing problems to fit a cool idea.
context_findings.quote: What you're doing right now, you have a solution and you're looking for a problem. But I want to implement solutions to my problems.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed distrust of large tech companies, believing Microsoft likely trains its AI models on user files uploaded to OneDrive.

Kaze has a nuanced view on the popular ROM hack 'Star Revenge,' acknowledging its popularity in the hardcore community but believing it's overrated and visually unappealing to a broader audience. He avoids public criticism to not 'be an asshole for no reason'.
context_findings.quote: My decision is to just let other people enjoy it and just for myself keep in the back of my mind, like this is not what the vast majority of people actually think.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works a day job at a game studio using Unreal Engine and is under an NDA, which is why he avoids using standard Visual Studio on stream.

biobak.summary: Kaze showed a screenshot of Biobak's graphical work on Course 11, praising his ability to turn a simple container model into a detailed, weathered asset.
biobak.quote: It's crazy. Looks so much better already. It looks like it has so much depth.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback in chat, suggesting the saloon doors Kaze was modeling were too large, which Kaze then acted upon.
biobak.quote: So you think my saloon doors look like shit? I see, I see.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned that Zeina ('Zeno') is creating textures for the signs in the western-themed level.
Kaze revealed he and Zeina ('Aza'/'Eiza') have collaborated on a separate, smaller ROM hack, indicating a creative partnership outside of their defined roles on RTYI.
zeina.quote: I wish Aza was here so I could get the permission to show our compact.

zeina.summary: Kaze shared a personal detail that Zeina's family is very religious, suggesting a familiarity with her life outside of the project.

key_stories.title: The Stubborn Saloon Doors
key_stories.summary: Kaze's frustrating, multi-step struggle to program swinging saloon doors perfectly encapsulates the development process. It involved a difficult technical bug hunt, community-driven artistic iteration, and the eventual satisfaction of a simple fix solving a complex-seeming problem.
key_stories.challenge: Implementing physically interactive swinging saloon doors that behaved correctly when pushed or punched from either side.
key_stories.process: Kaze struggled with the C code for rotation, leading to the doors swinging in the wrong direction. During this debugging process, he also received and acted on community feedback to resize the doors and improve their 3D model and texture, iterating on both the technical and artistic aspects simultaneously.
key_stories.outcome: After a long period of frustrating trial-and-error, Kaze identified a single incorrect variable in his physics code. The fix was simple, and resulted in a fully functional and visually improved set of doors.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, the doors go the wrong direction again. Are you fucking kidding me? What what the fuck am I doing wrong here?

key_stories.title: Pitch-Perfect Audio
key_stories.summary: To make a character's voice deeper, Kaze embarked on a full refactor of part of the audio engine. He built a new, efficient system from the ground up based on a core philosophy of 'zero cost for unused features', demonstrating his focus on creating robust, performant systems rather than simple hacks.
key_stories.challenge: The need to dynamically change the pitch of sound effects for specific characters, like the antagonist Boshi, without creating performance issues.
key_stories.process: Kaze first analyzed his old, inefficient method. He then refactored the core audio engine to apply a frequency scale modifier, guided by the principle that unused features should have zero performance impact. Finally, he extended this new system to be controlled by the game's dialogue data.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a new, efficient system for pitching audio. He also tied it to the dialogue system, allowing sound pitches to be defined directly in a character's text box data, creating a powerful and reusable feature.
key_stories.key_quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost. If you're not using that part of codes.

key_stories.title: The Savestate Rapper
key_stories.summary: Kaze collaborated directly with a community member to write and edit rap lyrics for an anti-cheating character. The process involved Kaze acting as an editor, checking the writing against strict technical limitations, and showcasing a deep level of community involvement in the game's creative content.
key_stories.challenge: To finalize and implement the dialogue for a secret anti-savestate character, ensuring the text was humorous and fit within the game's technical constraints.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviewed rap lyrics submitted by community member B-Turk. He acted as an editor, analyzing syllable counts to fit text box limits, judging the flow of the rhymes, and rejecting lines that didn't work. This collaborative process turned community content into a finished in-game feature.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully integrated the community-submitted raps into the game, creating a polished and funny Easter egg that directly engages with player behavior.
key_stories.key_quote: it has to be 8 exactly, otherwise it doesn't render right

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that the game is 'RSP bottlenecked' and that he's relying on a contributor named Sauren who is working on 'FBDX3' to help fix it.
questions: What does it mean for the game to be 'RSP bottlenecked' and how does that limit what you can create?
Can you explain in more detail what Sauren's work on FBDX3 entails and what impact you hope it has?
How has this major technical constraint shaped the overall design and scope of Return to Yoshi's Island?

open_questions.context: Kaze contrasted his design philosophy of creating a 'new experience' with other hacks that focus on 'vanilla movement', specifically mentioning Star Revenge.
questions: Could you expand on what a 'new experience' means to you in the context of a SM64 hack?
What are the core design pillars of RTYI that you feel best exemplify this philosophy?
How do you balance creating something fundamentally new while still making it feel respectful to the original game?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that he and his wife, Zeina, collaborated on a separate, small ROM hack he called their 'compact'.
questions: You mentioned a side project you made with Zeina. Can you tell us about that?
How does your creative collaboration on other projects influence your work together on RTYI?
What is the dynamic like when you are collaborating purely as creative partners versus your defined roles on a larger team?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that the team often hangs out in 'Dan's voice channel' and has recurring debates about technical topics like shadows.
questions: What is 'Dan's voice channel' and what role does this informal space play in the team's development process?
Can you describe the friendly arguments about 'shadows and graph nodes'? What are the different viewpoints?

open_questions.context: Kaze expressed a desire for custom music for the duel minigame, but the stream used placeholder music. Badub is the team's composer but was not mentioned.
questions: What is the process for getting custom music made for a new feature or level?
How do you brief Badub on the feeling or style you want for a piece of music?
How much of the final soundtrack do you envision being fully original compositions?
